editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: Catch that Catch can: OR, THE SECOND PART OF THE Musical Companion; BEING A COLLECTION OF New CATCHES, SONGS, and GLEES, Never printed before.

LONDON, Printed by J.P. for John Playford, at his Shop near the Templ â€¢
Church, 1685.

div.head: To all LOVERS of MUSIC.
div.p: IN my Preface before the Fifth Book of Ayres and Songs lately published, I gave several Reasons for my Resolution of forbearing for the future to make any more Collections of that nature, leaving it to my Son, and Mr. Carr's Son; but having for some years past gathered into one Book divers new Catches, Songs, and Glees, much like those in my Musical Companion, which I did only to recreate my self with my Musical Friends, I am prevailed with at their request (and for common benefit) to make them public; and because of their Similitude, give them the Title of the Second Part of the Musical Companion. The First Part contains about 100 Rounds and Catches, 6 Dialogues, 33 Ayres and Songs for two Voices, 60 choice Ayres, Songs, and Glees for three Voices, and 12 Ayres and Songs for four Voices. This Second Part contains 70 new Catches and Songs for two, three, and four Voices, many of them were printed from the Authors own Copies, and the rest from the truest Copies I could procure; however it is probable, that by often transcribing some Errors may have crept in, which has occasion'd me to print a smaller number than usual, thereby to make way for a second and more correct Impression, hoping such Gentlemen as find any Errors will be so kind as to rectifie them, by sending me some truer Copies. Some faults there are in the words, which an intelligent Musical Reader will easily perceive, and mend with a Pen. I am,

div.head: A Table of the Catches, Songs, and Glees, in this Book.

div.head: 1 A. 3 Voc. [Æ²pon Christchurch Bells in Oxford.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ OH the bonny Christchurch Bells, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6; they sound so woundy great, so wond'rous sweet, and they trowl so merâ•Œriâ•Œly, merâ•Œriâ•Œly: Oh the first and second Bell, that eâ•Œveâ•Œry day at Four and Ten, cries, Come, come, come, come, come to Pray'rs, and the Virger troops before the Dean: Tinkle, tinkle, ting, goes the small Bell at Nine, to call the Beerers home, but the Dev'l a Man will leave his Can, 'till he hears the mighty Tom.

div.head: Other words to the same Tune.
div.l: HArk the merry Tinker's crew, Nell, Doll, Moll, Kate, and Sue;
And they Chat so merrily, merrily.
Hark, the bawling Brats do cry,
Along the Streets as you pass by,
Oh, good Sir, pray Sir, one Farthing,
And thus the Bantlins never lin:
Tink, tink, tink, tink, tink, goes the Fryingpan,
But the Dev'l a Jade (to call the Doxies hom;

div.head: 2 A. 3 Voc. [Bartholomew Fair.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ HEre's that will challenge all the Fair, come buy my Nuts and Damsons, my Burâ•Œgaâ•Œmy Pears; here's the Whore of Baâ•Œbyâ•Œlon, the Devil and the Pope, the Girl is just a goâ•Œing on the Rope: Here's Diâ•Œves and Laâ•Œzaâ•Œrus, and the World's Creâ•Œaâ•Œtion, here's the Dutch Woman, the like's not in the Nation; here's the Booth where the tall Dutch Maid is, here are Bears that dance like aâ•Œny Ladies. Toâ•Œta, toâ•Œta, tot, goes the litâ•Œtle Peâ•Œny Trumpet, here's your Jaâ•Œcob Hall that can jump it, jump it; sound Trumpet, sound, a silâ•Œver Spoon and Fork, come here's your dainâ•Œty Pig and Pork.

div.head: 3 â€¢ . 4 Voc.
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰
JOhn ask'd his Land{dash}laâ•Œdy, thinkâ•Œing no ill, where he might best set up a Waâ•Œter{dash}Mill; the wanâ•Œton Laâ•Œdy seeâ•Œing John all aâ•Œlone, returâ•Œned her Answer to her Servant John: Would'st thou all oâ•Œthers thy Mill should disgrace? Then beâ•Œtwixt my Legs will be the fitâ•Œtest place; for I in time of need, can from beâ•Œhind, when Waâ•Œter fails before, supply't with Wind.

div.head: 4 A. 3 Voc. [Tom Jolly's Nose.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰
TOm Jolâ•Œly's Nose I mean to aâ•Œbuse, thy Jolâ•Œly Nose Tom provokes my Muse; thy Nose jolâ•Œly Tom that shines so bright, I'le eaâ•Œsiâ•Œly folâ•Œlow it by its own light: Thy Nose Tom Jolâ•Œly no Jest it will bear, although it yields Matâ•Œter enough, and to spare; but jolâ•Œly Tom's Nose, for all he can do, breeds Worms in it self, and in our Heads too. Tom's Nose, jolâ•Œly Tom's Nose, the more it is batâ•Œter'd, the more it glows: Then drink to Tom Jolâ•Œly a cooâ•Œling Glass, or jolâ•Œly Tom's Nose will fire his Face.

div.head: 5 A. 3 Voc. [Answer to Tom Jolly's Nose.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ ALthough jolâ•Œly Tom great Fame thou hast won, thy blooâ•Œdy red Nose shall look paâ•Œler e're long; for the rate that we drink at each night, still procures such Noâ•Œses as would quite discountenance yours: And when the large Bumâ•Œper floats round in the close, we'l despise thee, and swear, 'tis mine Arse of a Nose.

div.head: 6 A. 4 Voc. [The King's Health.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ GOD preserve his Maâ•Œjeâ•Œsty, and for eâ•Œver send him Viâ•Œctoâ•Œry, and conâ•Œfound all his Eâ•Œneâ•Œmies, drink off your Wine Sir. Repeat Amen all the while this Catch is singing, resting four Crotchets.
Aâ•Œmen.

div.head: 7 A. 3 Voc. [Gallopping Joan.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰
JOan has been galâ•Œlopâ•Œping, galâ•Œlopâ•Œping, galâ•Œlopâ•Œping, Joan has been gallopping all the Town o're; 'till her Bumfiddle, Bumfiddle, Bumfiddle, that 'till her Bumâ•Œfidâ•Œdle was wonderous sore; without e're a Sadâ•Œdle upon her old Jade, to fetch her good Man from the Alehouse trade.

div.head: 8 A. 3 Voc. [Second Part of Gallopping Joan.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ THis gallopping, gallopping Joan, I conclude, has an Instrument sucks, sucks more than Leech or Pump: She at preâ•Œsent, poor Girl, has no time to be lewd, for her Buttocks are so sore she cannot jump; but how-eâ•Œver you may tickle her Virâ•Œgiâ•Œnal Rump, for plainâ•Œly I see with your Mouth how you mump.

div.head: 9 A. 4 Voc. [Young John the Gardiner.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ YOung John the Gard'ner haâ•Œving lateâ•Œly got a veâ•Œry rich and ferâ•Œtile Garden Plot; bragging to Joan, quoth he, so rich a Ground for Mellons canâ•Œnot in the World be found: That's a damn'd lye, quoth Joan, for I can tell, a place that does your Garâ•Œden far exâ•Œcell: Where's that? says John, in mine Arse, quoth Joan, for there is store of Dung and Waâ•Œter all the year.

div.head: 10 A. 4 Voc. [Jumping Joan.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰
JOan, Joan, for your part, you love kissing with all your Heart; by my Trothâ–ª do I, says jumâ•Œping Joan, and therefore to you I make my moan.

div.head: 11 A. 3 Voc. [Kind Jenny.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ I'Le tell my Moâ•Œther my Jenâ•Œny cries, and then a poor languishing Loâ•Œver dies; but e'ye faith I beâ•Œlieve the Gipâ•Œsey lies, for all she looks so grave and wise: She longs to be tickl'd, to be tickl'd, to be tickl'd, she longs to be tickl'd; Oh! she longs to be tickl'd.

div.head: 12 A. 3 Voc. [The Maid with a Basket.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ ONce I did see a Maid with a Basâ•Œket hanging dangling on her Arm; she lay down as soon as I ask'd it, and rose aâ•Œgain without hurt or pain: And trip'd it merâ•Œriâ•Œly, and trip'd it merâ•Œriâ•Œly, merâ•Œriâ•Œly, merâ•Œriâ•Œly o're the Plain.

div.head: 13 A. 4 Voc. [A Farewel to Wives.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ ONce in our lives let us drink to our Wives, tho' the numâ•Œber of them is but small; God take the best, and the Dev'l take the rest, and so we shall be rid of 'em all.

div.head: 14 A. 3 Voc.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ AS I went oâ•Œver Tawâ•Œny Marsh, there I met with a tawâ•Œny Lass; tawâ•Œny Hose, and tawâ•Œny Shoon, tawâ•Œny Petâ•Œtiâ•Œcoat, tawny Gown; tawny Brows, and tawny Face, thy tawâ•Œny Nose in her tawâ•Œny Arse.

div.head: 15 A. 4 Voc.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ TIS Women makes us love, 'tis Love that makes us sad; 'tis Sadness makes us drink, and drinking makes us mad.

div.head: 16 A. 3 Voc. [A scolding Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ FY nay, preâ•Œthee John, do not quarâ•Œrel man, let's be merâ•Œry, and drink aâ•Œbout; you are a Rogue, you cheated me, I'le prove before this Company, I care not a Farthing for all you are so stout: Sir, you lye, I scorn your words, orâ–ª aâ•Œny Man that wears a Sword, for all you huff, who cares a Turd, or who cares for you.

div.head: 17 A. 3 Voc. [A Catch on Mum Saint.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ STrange News from the Rose Boys, neâ•Œver heard beâ•Œfore Boys; Saint upon a Sunâ•Œday he play'd aâ•Œway his Clothes Boys, neâ•Œver such a Saint was there eâ•Œver heard beâ•Œfore Boys.

div.head: 18 A. 3 Voc. [The Nut-brown Lass.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ A Health, a Health to the Nutâ•Œbrown Lass, with the Haâ•Œzle Eyes; she that has good Eyes, has alâ•Œso good Thighs, let it pass, let it pass: As much to the liveâ•Œliâ•Œer Gray, they're as good by night as day; she that has good Eyes, has alâ•Œso good Thighs, drink aâ•Œway, drink away: I'le pledge, Sir, I'le pledge, what ho! some Wine, here! some Wine; to mine, and to thine; to thine, and to mine; the Colours are Divine: But Oh! the Black Eyes, the Black, give me as much aâ•Œgain, and let it be Sack; She that has good Eyes, has alâ•Œso good Thighs, and a better knack.

div.head: 19 A. 3 Voc. [A Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ TO thee, to thee, and to a Maid that kindly will upâ•Œon her back be laid; and laugh, and sing, and kiss, and play, and wanâ•Œton, wanâ•Œton out a Sumâ•Œmers day: Such, such a Lass, kind Friends, and drinking, give me, great Jove, and damn, and damn the thinking.

div.head: 20 A. 4 Voc. [A Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ HAve you not in a Chimney seen, a Faâ•Œgot that is moyst and green, how it doth weep, and with its Tears, sends its Complaint unâ•Œto our Ears? So fares it with a tenâ•Œder Maid, when first upâ•Œon her Back she's laid: but dry Wood, like the experienc'd Dame, cracks and reâ•Œjoyâ•Œces in the Flame.

div.head: 21 â€¢ Voc. [A true Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ LEt's live good honest Lives, and make much of our Wives; and since all Flesh is Grass, let's merâ•Œriâ•Œly, merâ•Œriâ•Œly, merâ•Œriâ•Œly drink our Glass: God bless our noble King, what need we fear the Pope, the Pope, the Pope, the Pope, the Pope, the Pope, the Jeâ•Œsuits, Jews, or Turks? For we deâ•Œfie the Devil, the Devil, the Devil, the Devil, the Devil, the Devil, and all his Works.

div.head: 22 A. 3 Voc. [A right Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ THere are a crew of Rogues infect the Town, would undermine the Crown, the Whigs, the Whigs, the Whigs, the Whigs I mean; let all true Britains sing, They may be hang'd, may be hang'd, may be hang'd, may be hang'd, and so God save the King.

div.head: 23 A. 3 Voc. [The London Constable.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ WHo comes there? stand; who comes there? stand, and come before the Constable, we'l know what you are; what makes you out so late? says the Midâ•Œnight Maâ•Œgiâ•Œstrate, with a Nodâ•Œdle full of Ale, in a wooâ•Œden Chair of State. Whence come you, Sir? and whither do you go? you may be, Sir, a Jeâ•Œsuâ•Œit for ought I know: You may as well Sir take me for a Maâ•Œhoâ•Œmeâ•Œtan. He speaks Laâ•Œtin, seâ•Œcure him, he's a danâ•Œgeâ•Œrous Man. To tell you the truth, Sir, I am an hoâ•Œnest Toâ•Œry; but here's a Crown to drink, and there's an end of the stoâ•Œry. Good morrow Sir, a ciâ•Œvil Man is
alâ•Œways welâ•Œcom; go Barâ•Œnaâ•Œby Bounce, light the Gentleman home.

div.head: 24 A. 3 Voc. [The honest Royalist.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ COme, here's to the Man that lives quiâ•Œet, and follows his own Ocâ•Œcupaâ•Œtion; that sauâ•Œciâ•Œly dares not to fly at the setâ•Œled eâ•Œstate of the Nation: That neâ•Œver in Faction took pleasure, nor sign'd a seâ•Œdiâ•Œtious Petiâ•Œtion; whose Reâ•Œliâ•Œgion no Int'â•Œrest doth measure, whose Heart ne're commitâ•Œted misâ•Œpriâ•Œsion; but boldly dares own himself Loyâ•Œal to ev'â•Œry Phanaâ•Œtiâ•Œcal Rumper, and to all the Faâ•Œmiâ•Œly Royal most freeâ•Œly will take off his Bumper.

div.head: 25 A. 3 Voc. [The Loyal Citizen.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ SOme say the Plot goes on, and some for Reâ•Œbelâ•Œlion hope; but we'l combine to drink good Wine, in spite of Phaâ•Œnaâ•Œtic or Pope: Jack Presâ•Œbyâ•Œter huffs and dings, and Dirt on the Church he flings; the Ciâ•Œtiâ•Œzens swear they want but a May'r, to make them do wonâ•Œdeâ•Œrous things. But a Curse on all Knaves and Fools, sure we are not all such Owls; that twice in an Age they can eâ•Œver enâ•Œgage the Naâ•Œtion to damn their Souls.

div.head: 26 A. 5 Voc. [A small Quarrel.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ WHat's the matâ•Œter, what a Pox? nay, nay! nay, nay! prethee, prethee! what's the matâ•Œter? hey day!

div.head: 27 A. 4 Voc. [A Catch on a Horse.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ TIS eaâ•Œsie to force to the Waâ•Œter your Horse, but when h'as once had his Dose, he'l no more drench his Nose; that the Creature thus wise is, from hence it aâ•Œriâ•Œses, he finds his chill Fuddle meer Eâ•Œleâ•Œment and Puddle: Let the Tipâ•Œple be Wine, if the Horse proves not Swine, and drink all he's an Ass, tho' the Thames was his Glass; Greaâ•Œter Man on some strand more couragious should stand, and quaff, and quaff Seas in a hand.

div.head: 28 A. 3 Voc. [A Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ LET us love and drink our Liâ•Œquor, we shall spend our Means the quicker, here's to thee kind Friend a Nicâ•Œker.

div.head: 29 A. 3 Voc. [Judith and Holifernes.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ WHen Judith approach'd Hoâ•Œliâ•Œferâ•Œnes in bed, she pull'd out his Falchion, and cut off his Head; the reaâ•Œson is plain, he'd have made her his Whore, so she cut off his Head as I told you beâ•Œfore, as I told you before.

div.head: 30 A. 4 Voc. [The Thatcher.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ QUoth the Thatcher to his Man, Jack, what dost think? Let's raise this Ladder if we can, but first let's drink: No man can do more than a can, that's veâ•Œry plain; a Can may do's much as a Man, that's right again.

div.head: 31 A. 4 Voc. [An EPITAPH on an honest Citizen, and true Friend to all Claret-drinkers.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ HEre liâ•Œeth Syâ•Œmon cold as Clay, who whil'st he liv'd, cry'd, who whil'st he liv'd,
cry'd, Tip aâ•Œway; and when Death puts out his Taâ•Œper, he needeth no touch, he needeth no Touch upâ•Œon a Paâ•Œper. Now let him rest, since he is dead, and asks not for a bit, and asks not for a bit of Bread, before he dy'd, and that is much, for Death gave him, for Death gave him a Raâ•Œcey Touch.

lg.l: Now though this Epitaph was long since given,
Yet he's no more dead than any Man living.

div.head: 32 A. 4 Voc. [A Yorkshire Epitaph on two Abby Lubbers.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ UDS nigs! here ligs John Diggs, and Richard Digger, and to say the truth, to say the truth, none knew which was the bigger; they fared well, and liâ•Œved easie, and now they're dead, and now they're dead, and now they're dead, and shall please ye.

div.head: 33 A. 4 Voc. [A Councel for Married Folks.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ FRom twenty to thirty good night and good morrow; from thirâ•Œty to forâ•Œty good night or good morrow; from forâ•Œty to fifâ•Œty, as oft as ye shift ye; from thence to threescore, once a Month and no more.

div.head: 34 A. 3 Voc. [The Scolding Wife.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ MY Wife has a Tongue as good as e're twang'd, at evâ•Œry word she bids me be hang'd: She's ugâ•Œly, she's old, and a curâ•Œsed scold, with a damâ•Œnaâ•Œble Nunâ•Œquam saâ•Œtis; for her Tongue and her Tail, if eâ•Œver they fail, the Deâ•Œvil shall have her graâ•Œtis.

div.head: 35 A. 3 Voc. [Black Bess.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰
BEss black as a Charâ•Œcoal, was found in a dark hole, with Kit at the Cat and the Fidâ•Œdle; but what they did there, none safeâ•Œly can swear, yet Genâ•Œtleâ•Œmen ridâ•Œdle my Ridâ•Œdle. Troth, I would be loth, were I put to my Oath, to swear Kit with Bess did enâ•Œgenâ•Œder; yet it would tempt a Man, briâ•Œdle all that he can, his preâ•Œsent wellâ•Œwishâ•Œes to tenâ•Œder. But 'twas found at last, e're a Twelve-month was past, that Chriâ•Œstoâ•Œpher Bess had o'remaster'd; for betwixt eiâ•Œther Thigh he had quarter'd so nigh, she brought him a jolâ•Œly brown Baâ•Œstard.

div.head: 36 A. 3 Voc. [A Catch made in the time of Parliament, 1676.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ NOW England's great Council's assembled, to make Laws for all English-born Free-men; since 'tis dang'rous to prate of matters of State, let's handle our Wine, and our Woâ•Œmen: Let's drink to the Seâ•Œnates best Thoughts, for the good of the King and the Nation; may they dig on the Spot as deep for the Plot, as the Jeâ•Œsuits have laid the Founâ•Œdaâ•Œtion. A Pox of all Zeaâ•Œlots and Fool, and each silâ•Œly Proâ•Œteâ•Œstant haâ•Œter; betâ•Œter turn Cat in Pan, and live like a Man, than be hang'd and dye like a Traytor.

div.head: 37 A. 3 Voc. [The Jovial Drinker.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ LEt the grave Folks go Preach, that our Lives are but short, and tell us much Wine speedy Death does inâ•Œvite; but we'll be reâ•Œveng'd before-hand with them for't, and crowd a Life's Mirth in the space of a Night: Then stand all about with your â€¢ Glasâ•Œses full Crown'd, 'till ev'â•Œry thing elseâ–ª to our Posture do grow; 'till our â€¢ Cups and our Heads, and the whole House go round, and the Celler become where the Chamber is now. The Sun in the Rays of his rich Morâ•Œning Gown, shall be Rivall'd by Faâ•Œces as bright as his own; and wonder that Mortals canâ–ª fudâ•Œdle aâ•Œway more Wine in a night, than he Waâ•Œter i'th' day.

div.head: 38 A. 3 Voc. [Æ²pon the Duke's Return.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ SInce the Duke is return'd, we'l damn all the Whigs, and let them be hang'd for Poâ•Œliâ•Œtic Prigs; both Presâ•Œbyâ•Œter Jack, and all the whole Crew, that lateâ•Œly deâ•Œsign'd Forâ•Œty one to reâ•Œnew: Make room for the Man that neâ•Œver deny'd, to God save the King and Duke, they reply'd; whose Loyâ•Œalâ•Œty eâ•Œver was fix'd with that Zeal, of voâ•Œting down Schisme, and proud Commonweal. Then bring up a Potâ•Œtle, we'l Huzâ•Œza the Glass, and drink off a Botâ•Œtle each Man in his place; 'tis a Health to the Duke boy, give me my meaâ•Œsure, the fulâ•Œler the Glass is, the greaâ•Œter the Pleasure.

div.head: 39 â€¢ . 3 Voc. [A Loyal Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ GOD save our Sov'raign Charles, our Faith's Deâ•Œfenâ•Œder, let all good Men his Laws and Honour tenâ•Œder; protect Queen Cath'rine, England's nursing Mother, preserve York's Duke, our King's Ilâ•Œluâ•Œstrious Brother: Who to his piâ•Œous Votes deâ•Œnies his Hand, I pray for him too, but wish him out o'th' Land.

div.head: 40 A. 3 Voc. [In praise of Mum.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ THere's an odd sort of Liâ•Œquor new come from Hamborough, 'twill stitch a whole Wapentake thorough and thorough; 'tis yellow, and likewise as bitâ•Œter as Gall, and as strong as six Horses, Coach and all: As I told you, 'twill make you as drunk as a Drum; you'd fain know the name on't, but for that my friend MUM.

div.head: 41 A. 4 Voc. [A Catch on Tobacco, to be sung by 4 Men smoaking Pipes.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ GOod, good inâ•Œdeed, the Herb's good Weed, fill thy Pipe Will, and I, preâ•Œthee Sam fill, for sure we may smoak, and yet sing still, and yet sing still. What say the Learned? What say the Learned? Viâ•Œta fumus, viâ•Œta fuâ•Œmus; 'tis what you and I, and he and I, you, and he, and I, and all of us, Sumus. But then to the Learned say we aâ•Œgain, if Life's a Smoak as they maintain: If Life's a Vapour, without doubt, when a Man does dye, they should not cry, That his Glass is run, but, His Pipe is out. But whether we smoak, or whether we sing, let's be Loyal and remember
the King; let him live, and let his Foes vaâ•Œnish, thus, thus, thus, like, like a Pipe, like a Pipe of Spanish, thus, thus, like a Pipe of Spanish.

div.head: 42 A. 3 Voc. [Æ²pon small Beer.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ IF all true Friends of good Liquor now were here, were here, to club strongly in behalf of Small Beer, Small Beer, in behalf of hey diddle, ho diddle, hey Small Beer; it would all be too little the Tiff to exalt, and to make out in Metre what it wants in Malt: The French call it Little Beer, and we call it Small, and we call, we call it Small, and some sort of people neâ•Œver call for't at all: But I wish all those once, at least for their warning, Strong over night, much Stro â€¢ g oâ•Œver night, and no, no Small the next morning.

div.head: 43 [A Catch upon NOTHING.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ SIng merâ•Œriâ•Œly now my Lads, here's a Catch that was never meant you, but came by the Wheel of Fortune, without aâ•Œny deâ•Œsign or intent you; it happen'd that once the Author his Head was exâ•Œceeâ•Œding hot, a Catch he resolv'd he would make, he would make, and he cou'dâ•Œn't tell of what: He thought of the Smoak the Weed affords, and it vanish'd all aâ•Œway; he thought of fine Ladies and their fine Lords, and yet he found nothing to say. He thought of a thousand Pound, but it wou'dâ•Œn't turn to account: He thought of the Pot, and he thought of the Plot, but nothing would come on't. At last he resolv'd, tho' nothing would do, that nothing should put him by Sir, but
noâ•Œthing to purâ•Œpose of Nothing he'd write, and no boâ•Œdy should be the wiâ•Œser. 'Tis noâ•Œthing to you if he would do so, and if Nothing's in't you find; then thank him for Nothing, and that will be more than eâ•Œver he deâ•Œsign'd.

div.head: 44 A. 3 Voc. [An Irish Catch.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰
PAâ•Œtrick and Pegâ•Œgy were playâ•Œing aâ•Œlone, quoth Paâ•Œtrick to Pegâ•Œgy, Oh hone, Oh hone; thy Belâ•Œly gangs up aâ•Œmain, bless our sweet Baâ•Œby, and weez have a pretâ•Œty one if it may be: Sing Lulâ•Œlaâ•Œby, Lulâ•Œlaâ•Œby, danâ•Œdle the Lad, if thouz be the Mammy on't, Ize be the Dad on't.

div.head: 45 A. 3 Voc. [A Catch on the Cats.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ YE Cats that at Midnight spit Love at each oâ•Œther, who best feel the Pangs of a pasâ•Œsioâ•Œnate Lover; I apâ•Œpeal to your scratches and tatâ•Œteâ•Œred Fur, if the busiâ•Œness of Love be no more than to pur. Old Laâ•Œdy Grimmalkin, with Goosberry Eyes, when a Kitten knew something for why she was wise; you find by experience the Love-fit's soon o're, Puss, Puss, lasts not long, but turns to Cat-whore. Men ride many Miles, Cats tread many Tiles, both hazard, both hazard their Necks in the fray; onâ•Œly Cats, if they fall from a House or a Wall, keep their Feet, mount their Tails, mount their Tails and away.

div.head: 46 A. 3 Voc. [In Praise of White-wine.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ LET chrystal White-wine cheer the drowâ•Œzy Mind, 'tis Claâ•Œret onâ•Œly leaves a stain beâ•Œhind; in the use of which, we do Bacchus disgrace, we make the God morâ•Œtal by painâ•Œting his face: He's not like a God, whose Iâ•Œmage is red; o're Night his Cheeks blush, in the Morning they're dead.

div.head: 47 A. 3 Voc. [In praise of Claret.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ A Hogshead was offer'd to Bacchus his Shrine, the God was ofâ•Œfenâ•Œded because 'twas White-wine; then curs'd in a passion, Damn't, rot it, and mar it, did'st ever know Bacchus drink other than Claret; So the jolâ•Œly red God having empty'd the White-wine, return'd the poor Vot'â•Œry the Hogshead to shite in.

div.head: 48 A. 4 Voc. [A Catch on the Crab.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ THE Crab of the Wood is sauce veâ•Œry good, for the Crab of the foaming Sea; and the Wood of the Crab is good for the Drab, that will not her Husband oâ•Œbey.

div.head: 49 A. 4 Voc. [Touch and go.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ COme, come pretâ•Œty Wenches, more nimbler than Eels, and buy my fine Boxes, my Stones, and my Steels; let me touch but your Tinder, and you would admire, how quickly my Steel and my Stones will give fire; touch and go, touch and go: They are as good Metâ•Œtle as e're came in Box, to fire all your Tinder with two or three knocks; take my Steel in your hand Wench, and try but a blow, y' faith I dare warrant 'tis true touch and go; touch and go, touch and go.

div.head: 50 A. 3 Voc. [A Catch upon a Liquor called Punch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ YOu may talk of brisk Claret, sing Praiâ•Œses of Sherry, speak well of Old Hock, Mum, Siâ•Œder, and Perâ•Œry, but you must drink Punch if you mean to be merâ•Œry: A Boul of this Liâ•Œquor the Gods beâ•Œing all at, thought good we should know it by way of new Ballad, as fit for both ours and their Highâ•Œnesâ•Œses Pallat. Then thanks to the Gods, those Tiplers above us, they've taught us to love, and therefore they love us, and to drink veâ•Œry hard is all they crave of us.

div.head: 51 A. 4 Voc. [A Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ I Lay with an old Man all the night, I turn'd to him, and he to me: he could not do so well as he should, but he would fain, but it would not be.

div.head: 52 A. 2 Voc. [CANTÆ²S.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ OLD Ch â€¢ ron thus preach'd to his Puâ•Œpil Aâ•Œchilâ•Œles, I'le tell you, I'le tell you young Gentleman what the Fate's will is: You my Boy, you my Boy, must go, must go, the Gods will have it so, to the Siege of Troy; thence never to return, thence never to return, never to return, never to return to Greece again, but before those Walls to be slain, but before those Walls to be slain, before those Walls, those Walls to be slain. Let not your noble Courage be cast down, let not your noble Courage be cast down, let not your noble Courage, let not your noble Courage be cast down, but all the while you lye beâ•Œfore the Town drink, all the while drink, all the while you lye before the Town drink, and drive Care aâ•Œway, drink and be merry, you'l ne're go the sooner, you'l ne're go the sooner, you'l ne're go the sooâ•Œner to the Styâ•Œgian Ferâ•Œry.

div.head:
52
â€¢ oc. [BASSÆ²S.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ OLD Charon thus preach'd to his Puâ•Œpil Aâ•Œchilâ•Œles, I'le tell you young Gentleman what the Fate's will is: You my Boy, you my Boy, must go, must go, the Gods will have it so, to the Siege of Troy; thence neâ•Œver to return, thence never to return, never to reâ•Œturn to Greece again, but before those Walls to be slain, but before those Walls to be slain, before those Walls to be slain. Let not your noble Courage be cast down, let not your noble Courage be cast down, let not your noble Courage be cast down, let not your noble Courage be cast down, but all the while you lye before the Town drink, all the while drink, all the while you lye before the Town drink, and drive Care away, drink and be merry, you'l ne're go the sooner, the sooner, you'l ne're go the sooner to the Stygian Ferry.

div.head: 53 A. 3. Voc. [A Loyal Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ COme my Hearts, play your parts with your Quarts, see none starts, for the King's Health is a drinking; then to his Highness see, see there Wine is, that has past the Test aâ•Œbove the rest, for those Healths deserve the best. They that shrink for their Chink, from their Drink, we will think, we will think, that of Treasons they are thinking.

div.head: 54 A. 4 Voc. [A Catch.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ COme lay by your Cares, and hang up all Sorrow, drink on, he's a Sot that e're thinks on to morrow; great store of brisk Claret supplies ev'â•Œry thing, and the Man that is drunk is as great as a King: Let none at Misfortunes and Losses repine,
but take a full Dose of the Juice of the Vine; Disâ•Œeaâ•Œses and Troubles are ne're to be found, but in the damn'd place where the Glass goes not round.

div.head: 55 A. 4 Voc. [The Marriage Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ HOW hapâ•Œpy a thing were a Wedding, and a Bedding, if a Man cou'd purchase a Wife for a Twelve-month and a day; but to live with her all a Man's life, for eâ•Œver and aye, 'till she grows quite as gray as a Cat, I thank you for that, good faith Master Parson, I thank you, I thank you for that.

div.head: 56 A. 3. Voc. [A Round.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ UP and down this World goes, down, down this World goes, up and down, up and down the World goes.

div.head: 57 A. 2 Voc. [The Oath to be taken at Dunmow in Essex, on the demand of a Flitch of Bacon.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ YOU shall swear by the custom of Confession, if ever you made Nuptial Transgression; be you either marry'd Man or Wife, by Houshold Brawls, or Contentious Strife; or otherwise at Bed or at Board, ofâ•Œfenâ•Œded one aâ•Œnoâ•Œther in Deed, or in Word; or since the Parish-Clerk said Amen, you wish'd your selves unmarry'd agen; or in twelve Months time and a day, reâ•Œpenâ•Œted not in Thought aâ•Œny way, but conâ•Œtiâ•Œnuâ•Œed true and just in Desire, as when you joyn'd Hands in holy Quire.

div.head: Chorus, 2 Voc.
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ IF to these Conâ•Œdiâ•Œtions without all fear, of your own acâ•Œcord you will IF to these Conâ•Œdiâ•Œtions without all fear, of your own acâ•Œcord you will
freeâ•Œly swear; a whole Gamâ•Œmon of Baâ•Œcon you shall reâ•Œceive, and bear it freeâ•Œly swear; a whole Gamâ•Œmon of Baâ•Œcon you shall reâ•Œceive, and bear it thence with Love and good leave: For this is our cuâ•Œstom in Dunâ•Œmow well thence with Love and good leave: For this is our cuâ•Œstom in Dunâ•Œmow well known; tho' the Pleaâ•Œsures are ours, yet the Baâ•Œcon's your own. known; tho' the Pleaâ•Œsures are ours, yet the Baâ•Œcon's your own.

div.head: 58 A. 4 Voc. [A Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ THe Hart he loves the high Wood, the Hare he loves the Hill; the Knight he loves his bright Sword, the Laâ•Œdy loves her will.

div.head: 59 A. 2 Voc. [CANTÆ²S.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ FILL the Boul, 'tis a Health to our Friends at Vienn; fill the Boul, 'tis a Health to our Friends at Vienn; he that leaves but one drop, he shall drink it aâ•Œgain. To Staremburgh's Health we will spring a new Myne, and each luâ•Œsty Barâ•Œrel shall be fill'd with brisk Wine; but when we reâ•Œmemâ•Œber the King of the Poles, we then wish our tall Steeples, our tall Steeples, were the drinking Bouls.

div.head: 59 A. 2 Voc. [BASSÆ²S.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ FILL the Boul, 'tis a Health to our Friends at Viâ•Œenn; fill the Boul, 'tis a Health to our Friends at Viâ•Œenn; he that leaves but one drop, that leaves but one drop, he shall drink it aâ•Œgain. To Staremburgh's Health we will spring a new Myne, and each luâ•Œsty Barâ•Œrel shall be fill'd with brisk Wine; but when we reâ•Œmemâ•Œber the King of the Poles, we then wish our tall Steeples were the drinking Bouls.

div.head: 60 A. 3 Voc. [A Musical Catch.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ UT La, Æ²t Fa Me, Fa Re La, Fa Re La, Fa Re La, Money; Fa Re La, Fa Re La, Fa Re La, Money. Æ²t La, Æ²t, &c.

div.head: 61 A. 3 Voc. [A Scotch Epitaph.]
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ MArry hem think'st thou liggeth here, eyn Jamey, eyn Jamey, the good Pyper; hem Jamey the yonker, fay, fay, fay, say, hem than Jamey the elâ•Œder, eay, eay.

div.head: 62 A. 2 Voc. [A Medly.] CANTÆ²S.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ WE live in Woods, we live in Groves, we scorn all Thoughts but of our Loves; we Lauâ•Œgh and Quaâ•Œff, 'till Cocks do crow, and grieve but when our Cups run low, and grieve but when our Cups run low. Red is our Noses, red is our Noses, rich is our Faâ•Œces, rich is our Faâ•Œces, free Mettle all, free Mettle all, but of no pace. We cannot Card, we cannot Spin, we cannot Spin, But we can drink, but we can drink all out, all out, all out, all out that's in. We have no Art to turn the Wheel, but yet we dare be bold to Reel, to Reeâ•Œl, be bold to Reel. Oh! let us make our Colours roar, let us Slow. make our Colours roar, so shall we sleep, shall we sleep, and snort, and snort, and snore; and neâ•Œver be drunk, and neâ•Œver be drunk aâ•Œny more; and neâ•Œver be, neâ•Œver be neâ•Œver be drunk aâ•Œny more.

div.head: 62 A. 2 Voc. [A Medley.] BASSÆ²S.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ WE live in Woods, we live in Groves, we scorn all Thoughts but of our Loves; we Lauâ•Œgh and Quaâ•Œff, 'till Cocks do crow, and grieve but when our Cups run low, and grieve but when our Cups run low. Red is our Noses, red is our Noses, rich is our Faces, rich is our Faces, free Mettle all, free Mettle all, but of no pace. We cannot Card, we cannot spin, we cannot spin, but we can drink, but we can drink all out, all out, all out, all out that's in. We have no Art to turn the Wheel, but yet we dare be bold to Reel, to Reeâ•Œl, be bold to Reel. Oh! let us make our Colours roar, let us Slow. make our Colours roar, so shall we sleep, shall we sleep, and snort, and snort, and snore; and neâ•Œver be drunk, and neâ•Œver be drunk aâ•Œny more; and neâ•Œver be, never be, neâ•Œver be drunk aâ•Œny more.

div.head: 63 A. 2 Voc. [A Glee.] CANTÆ²S.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ LET us drink to all the well{dash}wilâ•Œlers of the Church, and the Kingâ•Œly State, while the Good Old Cause fulâ•Œfilâ•Œlers are drunk with Maâ•Œlice and Hate; let us sing and obey whilst they whine and Rebel, for Muâ•Œsic's in Heav'n, but Witchcraft in Hell, for eâ•Œver and eâ•Œver must dwell, for eâ•Œver and eâ•Œver must dwell.

div.head: 63 A. 2 Voc. [A Glee.] BASSÆ²S.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ LET us drink to all the well{dash}wilâ•Œlers of the Church, and the Kingâ•Œly State, while the Good Old Cause fulâ•Œfilâ•Œlers are drunk with Malice and Hate; let us sing and oâ•Œbey, whilst they whine and Reâ•Œbel, for Muâ•Œsic's in Heav'n, but Witchcraft in Hell, for eâ•Œver and eâ•Œver must dwell, for eâ•Œver and eâ•Œver must dwell.

div.head: 64 A. 2 Voc. [A Glee.] CANTÆ²S.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ AWay with the Cauâ•Œses of Richâ•Œes and Cares, that eats up our Spiâ•Œrits, and shortens our Years; no Pleasure can be in State or Degree, but 'tis mingled with Trouble and Fears: Then perish all Fops of Sobriâ•Œeâ•Œty dull, whilst he that is merâ•Œry reigns Prince of the World.

div.head: 64 A. 2 Voc. [A Glee.] BASSÆ²S.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ AWay with the Cauâ•Œses of Richâ•Œes and Cares, that eats up our Spiâ•Œrits, and shortens our Years; no Pleaâ•Œsure can be in State or Degree, but 'tis mingled with Troubles and Fears: Then pe â•Œrish all Fops of Sobriâ•Œeâ•Œty dull, whilst he that is merâ•Œry reigns Prince of the World.

div.head: 67 A. 2 Voc. [Adieu to a Mistress.] CANTÆ²S.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ COme lay by all Care, e'ne let her go, fill up the Glass 'till it oâ•Œverflow; if the Drawer prove right, no Miâ•Œstress like Wine, she'l charm all your Senses, and Fancies refine: To humour a Creature will change like the Moon, sometimes she'l be kind, then dogged as soon. Prethee leave off! we'l mind her no more, and 'tis Chorus. forâ•Œty to one if she ben't a damn'd Whore. Then drink about freely, then drink aâ•Œbout freeâ•Œly whilst now in your pow'r, whilst now, now in your pow'r; then drink aâ•Œbout freely, then drink, then drink, drink about, drink aâ•Œbout freeâ•Œly, whilst now in your pow'r, ne're lose the great Blessing, ne're lose the great Blessing of this hapâ•Œpy hour.

div.head: 67 A. 2 Voc. [Adieu to a Mistress.] BASSÆ²S.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ COme lay by all Care, e'ne let her go, fill up the Glass 'till it oâ•Œver{dash}flow; if the Drawer prove right, no Mistress like Wine, she'l charm all your Senâ•Œses, and Fanâ•Œcies refine: To humour a Creature will change like the Moon, sometimes she'l be kind, then dogged as soon; prethee leave off! we'l mind her no more, and 'tis Chorus. forâ•Œty to one if she ben't a damn'd Whore. Then drink aâ•Œbout freely, then drink aâ•Œbout freeâ•Œly, whilst now in your pow'r, whilst now in your pow'r; then drink about freeâ•Œly, then drink aâ•Œbout freeâ•Œly, then drink, drink about, drink aâ•Œbout freeâ•Œly, whilst now in your pow'r, ne're lose the great Blessing, ne're lose the great Blessing of this hapâ•Œpy hour.

div.head: 68 A. 2 Voc. [CANTÆ²S.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ THo' my Miâ•Œstress be fair, yet froward, yet froâ•Œward she's too; then hang the dull Soul, then hang the dull Soul, that will ofâ•Œfer, will ofâ•Œfer to woo: But 'tis Wine, brave Wine, 'tis Liquor, 'tis Liquor, good Liâ•Œquor, that's much more sublime, much brisâ•Œker and quicker, much, much, much brisâ•Œker and quicker; it in sparâ•Œkles smiles on me, 'tho she frown upâ•Œon me: Then with laughâ•Œing and quaffing I'le Time and Age beguile, owe my Pimples and Wrinkles, owe my Pimples and Wrinâ•Œkles to my Drink and a Smile. Come fill up, come fill up my Glass, and aâ•Œpox on her Face; may it never want Scars and Scratches, may it neâ•Œver want Scars and Scratches, wash Paint and Patches:
Give me all my drinkâ•Œing Maâ•Œgaâ•Œzine, I'le bloâ•Œw up the scornful Quean; give me Botâ•Œtles and Jugs, the Glasâ•Œses and Mugs, I'le hug 'em, and tug 'em, I'le hug 'em, and tug 'em, and Court 'em much more, than e're I did the peeâ•Œvish Girl before, than e're I did, than e're I did the peeâ•Œvish Girl before.

div.head: 68 A. 2 Voc. [BASSÆ²S.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ THo' my Mistress be fair, yet froâ•Œward she's too; then hang the dull Soul, then hang the dull Soul, that will ofâ•Œfer to woo: But 'tis Wine, brave Wine, 'tis Liquor, good Liquor, that's much more sublime, much brisker and quicker, much, much, much brisker and quicker; it in sparkles smiles on me, tho'
she frown upon me: Then with laughâ•Œing and quaffing I'le Time and Age beguile, owe my Pimples and Wrinkles, owe my Pimples and Wrinkles to my Drink and a Smile. Come fill up my Glass, come fill up my Glass, and aâ•Œpox on her Face; may it neâ•Œver, may it neâ•Œver want Scars, want Scars and Scratches, wash Paint and Patches: Give me all my drinkâ•Œing Magazine, give me all, I'le bloâ•Œw up the scornful Quean; give me Bottles and Jugs, the Glasses and Mugs, I'le hug 'em, I'le hug 'em, and tug 'em, and Court 'em much more, than e're I did the peeâ•Œvish Girl before, than e're I did the peeâ•Œvish Girl before.

div.head: ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ . [For the 29th of May.] ALTÆ²S.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ AWake my Muse without delay, awake my ever tuneful Lute; to sing the Glories of his day, in your most soft and kind dispute: This Rising-Sun gave Charles his Birth, together rose the Sun and he; The mighty Sun to rule the Earth, and mighty Charles to rule the Sea.

div.head: 69 A. 3 Voc. [For the 29th of May.] MEDIÆ²S.
div.p: ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ AWake my Muse without delay, awake my ever tuneful Lute; to sing the Glories of his day, in your most soft and kind dispute: This Rising-Sun gave Charles his Birth, together rose the Sun and he; The mighty Sun to rule the Earth, and mighty Charles to rule the Sea.

div.head: 71 For a Bass alone. [Tom of Bedlam.]
div.p:
ã€ˆâ™«ã€‰ FOrth from the dark and disâ•Œmal Cell, or from the deen aâ•Œbyss of Hell; mad Tom is come to view the World aâ•Œgain, to see if he can cure his distemper'd Brain: Fears and Cares opâ•Œpress my Soul, hark how the anâ•Œgry Furies howl; Pluâ•Œto laughs, and Proâ•Œserâ•Œpine is glad, to see poor angry Tom of Bedlam mad. Through the World I wander night and day to find my stragling Senâ•Œses, in an anâ•Œgry mood I met old Time, with his Penâ•Œtaâ•Œteuch of Tenses; when me he spies, aâ•Œway he flies, for Time will stay for no â€¢ an; in vain with Cries, I rend the Skies, for Piâ•Œty is not common. Cold and comfortless
I lye, Help, help, oh help! or else I dye! Hark, I hear Aâ•Œpolâ•Œlo's Team, the Carman 'gins to whistle; Chast Diâ•Œaâ•Œna bends her Bow, and the Boar beâ•Œgins to briâ•Œstle. Come Vulâ•Œcan with Tools and with Tackles, to knock off my trouâ•Œbleâ•Œsom Shackles; bid Charles make reaâ•Œdy his Wain, to This Song was printed in the First Book of Choice Ayres, the Impression of which is all sold off, and this Song I am often enquired after, which caused me to reprint it in this place. bring me my Senâ•Œses aâ•Œgain.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Last night I heard the Dog-Star bark,
Mars met Venus in the the dark;
Lymping Vulcan heat an Iron Bar,
And furiously made at the great God of War.
Mars with his Weapon laid about,
Lymping Vulcan had got the Gout;
His broad Horns did hang so in his light,
That he could not see to aim his blows aright.
Mercury the nimble Post of Heaven
Stood still to see the Quarrel;

Gorrel- ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
â€¢ cchus, Gyant-like,
ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ Barrel
To me he drank, I did him thank,
But I could drink no Sider;
He drank whole Buts 'till he burst his Guts,
But mine was ne're the wider.
Poor Tom is very dry,
A little Drink for Charity.
Hark! I hear Acteon's Hounds,
The Huntsman hoops and hallows;
Ringwood, Rockwood, Jowler, Bowman,
All the Chafe doth follow.
The Man in the Moon drinks Claret,
Eats Powder'd-Beef, Turnep, and Carret;
But a Cup of Malago Sack
Will fire the Bush at his back.
